Award.AwardTitle: Dimensions: Collaborative Research: A community level approach to understanding speciation in Hawaiian lineages
Award.AbstractNarration:
Recent advances in biodiversity research have led to progress in two separate directions that focus first on how organisms change over time, and second on spatial patterns of biodiversity at a given time. The proposed research brings together these two approaches to understand biodiversity in a dynamic context. Fundamental research questions are: (1) how are the rate and order of diversification in different groups of organisms determined by the community in which they live, and (2) how does the sequence of diversification dictate the resulting community composition? The research focuses on insects and spiders and uses the known dynamic geology of the young islands of the Hawaiian archipelago, where different contemporary sites represent stages in a geological sequence, as a system for examining feedbacks between adaptation, population divergence, and associated community succession. Methods include: (1) genomic and other molecular tools to measure active diversification of interacting groups of species that are recent arrivals to these novel habitats, and (2) ecological and computational approaches to measure changes in species composition over time.

The research will determine the importance of changing roles of species within communities as populations diverge over time and assemble in space, and the role of that dynamic community in fostering diversification. The work also informs applied areas of invasion and conservation biology, and restoration ecology, by testing the importance of priority, sequence, and associated interaction strengths. The project will train multiple undergraduate and graduate students as well as postdocs in research at the intersection between evolutionary biology and ecology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Recent efforts to understand patterns of biodiversity have progressed actively, guided by two disparate approaches, ecological and evolutionary. Ecological approaches can provide detailed insights into the immediate factors that shape species at a given point in time, but generally cannot accommodate change through time. Evolutionary approaches provide insights into the dynamic behavior of specific lineages over space and time but can provide little information on community parameters and interactions. Our research aimed to merge these approaches by investigating species interactions and communities in an age-structured landscape in the Hawaiian Islands. Specifically, we aimed to understand signatures of how arthropod communities respond to change, using (1) the age of the volcano as a proxy for the age of the biological community, and hence looking at how communities have been modified over extended geological time.  And (2) elevation as a proxy for extent of habitat modification, given that there is a steep gradient of invasion from low to middle elevation habitats. The system is based on the idea that the DNA holds the key to 1) identify the species that live in an community because variations in DNA allow us to catalog life and separate native and introduced diversity, 2) reconstruct the network of interactions (e.g. predator-prey, pollination, etc.), almost all of which involve a detectable trace of DNA, to infer how the ecosystem is changing and identify tipping points; and 3) assess population trends, because the genomes of species record their history of change, whether they are growing or shrinking.

Intellectual Merit: Unless we develop new approaches to assessment of biodiversity, it will take centuries to identify attributes that make an ecosystem robust and resilient to change.  Our research has allowed us to develop a set of metrics of ecosystem health based on the balance of abundance across species and the structure of interaction networks, and how these metrics are modified in the face of habitat modification and loss, and invasive species. The results of this work have shown that (1) arthropods from communities of arthropods on the youngest volcanoes have broader ecological ranges, those on older volcanoes occupy more restricted ranges, indicating greater specialization. This appears to be associated with; (2) more complex networks of interaction networks that increase in complexity of the geological timeframe provided by the islands. Both these are linked to (3) lower resilience of younger communities to invasion by non natives. The proportion of non native species is much higher on the younger islands.  

Broader Impacts: The world?s ecosystems are under serious threat due to ongoing stressors of the Anthropocene: notably habitat destruction, climate change, disease, and the spread of invasive species. Understanding how ecosystems change under these threats in real time is a major challenge for society, and one we are currently not meeting. Global threats are concentrated intensively on islands, allowing them to serve as harbingers of what the future may hold for the world at large. In the course of our work in the Hawaiian Islands we have developed an unprecedented set of quantitative empirical data based on metabarcoding of entire arthropod communities across gradients of space and time.The pipeline we have developed has the potential to transform our ability to census communities rapidly and provide fine-scale measurements of species richness and turnover, as well as trophic links. These data are amenable to integrative and predictive theoretical analyses to characterize communities based on abundances, interaction networks, and genetic distributions. The promise of this approach as a way to provide insights into the ?health? of biological communities globally is quite profound, as it provides a way to encapsulate the ?status? of the biological component of an ecosystem and allows comparison across space and time, yet is agnostic to species identity.

Over the course of the research we have trained 11 postdocs, 16 graduate students, 64 undergraduates, and one high school student. We have also developed national and international collaborations and networks, including with the German Centre for Integrative Biodiversity Research (iDiv and sDiv), the Japanese Okinawa Institute of Science and Technology (OIST), and the Funda??o Luso-Americanafor parallel work on the islands of the Azores. We are also working on building out from the current effort to develop a project  in collaboration with OIST, and working closely with a similar effort in Europe, iBioGen, that focuses on Island Genomic Observatories to develop models for improving our understanding of processes that shape the diversity and dynamics of island communities.
